summary: This is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel discussing a recent oral argument before Judge Engelmayer regarding a FOIA request related to Jeffrey Epstein. The judge expressed skepticism about the breadth of the government's withholdings under Exemption 7(A) and ordered an in camera review, specifically questioning withholdings related to the Tartaglione case versus the broader Noel case.

persons.name: Judge Engelmayer
persons.context: Presided over the oral argument in the Epstein FOIA case, expressed skepticism about the government's 7(A) withholdings, and ordered an in camera review of the withheld documents.

persons.name: Audrey
persons.context: The judge directed the email author to communicate with Audrey to have her reconsider the FOIA response and potentially confer with Main Justice, especially in light of the recent change in administration.

persons.name: Tartaglione
persons.context: A criminal case (likely involving Nicholas Tartaglione) that is cited as a basis for withholding documents under Exemption 7(A) in the Epstein FOIA request. The judge wants material withheld specifically for this case to be marked separately.

persons.name: Noel
persons.context: A criminal case (likely involving Ghislaine Maxwell, whose full name is Ghislaine Noelle Maxwell) that is cited as the broader basis for withholding documents under Exemption 7(A) in the Epstein FOIA request. The judge inquired about which withheld materials had been produced to the Noel defendants under Rule 16.

persons.name: PAE
persons.role: Presiding Agency Employee (likely a FOIA officer or reviewer)
persons.context: Described as being 'very skeptical of withholding w/r/t Tartaglione.' The email author disagrees with PAE's assessment, believing their office's withholdings were the narrowest.

connections.description: Judge Engelmayer directed the email author to communicate with Audrey to have her reconsider the FOIA response and potentially confer with Main Justice.

Both are subjects of separate criminal cases used as justification for withholding documents under Exemption 7(A) in the Epstein FOIA litigation. The judge ordered material withheld for Tartaglione to be marked separately from material withheld for the broader Noel case.

events.title: Oral Argument in Epstein FOIA Case
events.description: A roughly two-hour oral argument was held before Judge Engelmayer regarding the government's withholdings in response to a FOIA request related to Jeffrey Epstein. The judge was skeptical of the breadth of the 7(A) exemptions.

events.title: Expected Court Order for In Camera Review
events.description: The court is expected to issue an order directing the government to produce withheld documents for the judge's private, in camera review and to specifically mark material withheld in connection with the Tartaglione case.

keyFacts: Judge Engelmayer ordered an in camera review of documents withheld by the government in an Epstein-related FOIA request, expressing significant skepticism about the breadth of the Exemption 7(A) withholdings.

The court specifically questioned the distinction between material withheld due to the Tartaglione criminal case and material withheld due to the broader Noel (likely Ghislaine Maxwell) criminal case.
The judge inquired about which withheld materials had already been produced to the Noel defendants under Rule 16 discovery rules.

The judge suggested the recent change in administration (from Trump to Biden) might have a bearing on the FOIA response and directed communication with 'Audrey' to reconsider the government's position.
